Subject: English
QuestionText: A sentence begins with a capital letter.

Subject: English
QuestionText: A sentence ends with a period question mark or exclamation point.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The word "cat" has three sounds.

Subject: English
QuestionText: In the sentence "The dog runs" the word "runs" tells what the dog does.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The word "I" is always written with a capital letter.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The sentence "The sun is hot" has correct capitalization. {eng_tf_g1_q6.png}

Subject: English
QuestionText: In the story a girl finds a red ball. The ball is red. So the main thing she found is a ball.

Subject: English
QuestionText: Two words can have the same meaning.

Subject: English
QuestionText: We write "the dog" not "the Dog" when it is not at the start of a sentence.

Subject: English
QuestionText: A question must end with a period.

Subject: English
QuestionText: A noun names a person place or thing.

Subject: English
QuestionText: An adjective describes a noun.

Subject: English
QuestionText: In "The cats play" the subject and verb agree.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The word "unhappy" has a prefix that means "not."

Subject: English
QuestionText: In the passage "It was a rainy day. We stayed inside." the two sentences are correctly separated.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The sign says "No running." So we should walk. {eng_tf_g2_q6.png}
Description: Image: sign with rule; infer behavior.

Subject: English
QuestionText: In "She runs fast" the word "fast" tells how she runs.

Subject: English
QuestionText: A comma is used between the day and year in a date.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The sentence "The boy and the girl plays" has correct subject-verb agreement.

Subject: English
QuestionText: In the short text the fox hid under a bush. So the fox was hiding.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The subject of a sentence tells who or what the sentence is about.

Subject: English
QuestionText: A paragraph can have more than one main idea.

Subject: English
QuestionText: Quotation marks are used around the exact words someone said.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The word "reread" contains a prefix meaning "again."

Subject: English
QuestionText: In "The dogs bark loudly" the subject is plural and the verb agrees.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The sentence "Where did you go" needs a question mark at the end. {eng_tf_g3_q6.png}

Subject: English
QuestionText: In the passage "The bird built a nest. It laid three eggs." the word "It" refers to the bird.

Subject: English
QuestionText: A compound sentence joins two related ideas with a comma and conjunction.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The author wrote "The sky turned dark" mainly to show setting.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The sentence "He don't like it" uses correct grammar.

Subject: English
QuestionText: A run-on sentence joins two or more sentences without correct punctuation or conjunction.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The comparative form of "big" is "bigger."

Subject: English
QuestionText: In the text "The storm damaged the roof. Repairs cost a lot." the second sentence is a detail that supports the first.

Subject: English
QuestionText: A possessive noun shows ownership.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The sentence "She goed to the store" has a verb error.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The paragraph has a topic sentence followed by supporting details. {eng_tf_g4_q6.png}

Subject: English
QuestionText: In "The team won the game. They were happy." the word "They" refers to the team.

Subject: English
QuestionText: Revising for clarity means making the writing easier to understand.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The word "unnecessary" has a prefix and a suffix.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The sentence "Me and him went" uses correct pronoun case.

Subject: English
QuestionText: A clause must have a subject and a verb.

Subject: English
QuestionText: Correlative conjunctions like "either...or" come in pairs.

Subject: English
QuestionText: In the passage the narrator describes the forest as quiet and dark. So the mood is calm and cheerful.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The sentence "The list includes apples oranges and bananas" needs commas between items.

Subject: English
QuestionText: An idiom is a phrase whose meaning is different from the literal meaning of the words.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The author uses headings and subheadings to organize the article. {eng_tf_g5_q6.png}

Subject: English
QuestionText: In "After the game we went home" the word "After" begins a dependent clause.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The sentence "Their going to the park" has a spelling error that changes meaning.

Subject: English
QuestionText: Editing includes checking spelling punctuation and grammar.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The word "disagree" has a prefix that means "not" or "opposite."

Subject: English
QuestionText: A pronoun must agree in number with its antecedent.

Subject: English
QuestionText: In "The data shows a trend" the singular subject "data" can take a singular verb in formal use.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The author states "Sales increased by 20%." So the author is making a claim supported by data.

Subject: English
QuestionText: Active voice means the subject performs the action.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The sentence "She is older than me" uses correct pronoun case after "than."

Subject: English
QuestionText: The passage uses cause-and-effect structure to explain the outcome. {eng_tf_g6_q6.png}

Subject: English
QuestionText: A colon can introduce a list.

Subject: English
QuestionText: In the story the character avoids conflict. So we can infer the character prefers peace.

Subject: English
QuestionText: A thesis statement should state the main point of an essay.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The word "benevolent" in "a benevolent ruler" likely means kind or generous.

Subject: English
QuestionText: A modifier should be placed next to the word it modifies.

Subject: English
QuestionText: In "Neither the teacher nor the students were ready" the verb agrees with the closer subject.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The author compares the city to a beehive. So the author is using a simile.

Subject: English
QuestionText: A semicolon can join two closely related independent clauses.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The sentence "The reason is because" is redundant.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The chart shows three main categories. {eng_tf_g7_q6.png}

Subject: English
QuestionText: In the argument the author gives two reasons and then a conclusion. So the structure is logical.

Subject: English
QuestionText: Using "they" as a singular pronoun for a known person is accepted in modern usage.

Subject: English
QuestionText: A counterclaim presents an opposing view in an argument.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The word "audacious" in "an audacious plan" likely means bold or daring.

Subject: English
QuestionText: A verb in the subjunctive mood can express a wish or condition contrary to fact.

Subject: English
QuestionText: In "If I were you I would go" the verb "were" is correct in formal English.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The author uses a first-person narrator. So the reader sees only that character's thoughts.

Subject: English
QuestionText: An ellipsis can show that words were omitted from a quotation.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The sentence "Each of the students has their book" may be revised for formal agreement.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The infographic summarizes the main steps. {eng_tf_g8_q6.png}

Subject: English
QuestionText: In the passage the author appeals to logic by citing statistics. So this is an appeal to ethos.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The word "ambiguous" means unclear or having more than one meaning.

Subject: English
QuestionText: A strong conclusion restates the main idea and leaves a final thought.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The phrase "due to the fact that" can often be replaced with "because."

Subject: English
QuestionText: In "The team are playing well" British usage allows a collective noun with a plural verb.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The author uses dark imagery in the opening. So the tone is likely serious or somber.

Subject: English
QuestionText: A dash can set off an abrupt break or emphasis in a sentence.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The sentence "Neither of the options are suitable" has a subject-verb agreement error in formal writing.

Subject: English
QuestionText: In the argument the author refutes the opposing view. So the author is addressing a counterclaim.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The passage uses formal diction and complex sentences. {eng_tf_g9_q6.png}

Subject: English
QuestionText: The word "pragmatic" in "a pragmatic approach" means practical.

Subject: English
QuestionText: Claims in an essay should be supported by evidence from the text or research.

Subject: English
QuestionText: Parallel structure means using the same grammatical form for items in a series.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The phrase "in order to" can often be shortened to "to."

Subject: English
QuestionText: Who is used for subjects and ""whom"" for objects in formal English.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The author shifts from past to present tense to create immediacy. So the shift is intentional.

Subject: English
QuestionText: A comma splice joins two independent clauses with only a comma.

Subject: English
QuestionText: In "The data suggest a trend" the verb "suggest" agrees with the collective noun "data."

Subject: English
QuestionText: The source is from a university. So it is likely credible for academic writing.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The sentence contains a nonrestrictive clause set off by commas. {eng_tf_g10_q6.png}

Subject: English
QuestionText: The word "ubiquitous" means rare or uncommon.

Subject: English
QuestionText: A works cited list gives full publication details for sources used.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The author uses irony when the character says the opposite of what is meant.

Subject: English
QuestionText: Avoiding plagiarism means giving credit when you use someone else's ideas or words.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The subjunctive "I suggest that he go" is correct in formal English.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The author alludes to a famous historical event. So the reader needs context to fully understand.

Subject: English
QuestionText: A restrictive clause is not set off by commas because it is essential to the meaning.

Subject: English
QuestionText: In the satire the author exaggerates flaws to criticize society.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The sentence "The committee has issued their report" may be revised to avoid a pronoun agreement issue.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The graph supports the author's claim about trends. {eng_tf_g11_q6.png}

Subject: English
QuestionText: The word "paradigm" often means a model or framework.

Subject: English
QuestionText: A synthesis essay combines ideas from multiple sources into a coherent argument.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The author uses a periodic sentence to create emphasis by delaying the main idea.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The phrase "at this point in time" can be replaced with "now."

Subject: English
QuestionText: The passive voice is appropriate when the doer of the action is unknown or less important.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The author uses stream of consciousness. So the narrative follows the character's thoughts closely.

Subject: English
QuestionText: An apostrophe is used to form the possessive of a plural noun ending in s.

Subject: English
QuestionText: In academic writing hedging language (e.g. "may" "suggest") can show appropriate caution.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The author appeals to pathos by describing emotional experiences.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The excerpt uses technical vocabulary appropriate for the discipline. {eng_tf_g12_q6.png}

Subject: English
QuestionText: The word "equivocate" means to be vague or avoid commitment.

Subject: English
QuestionText: A primary source is a first-hand account or original document.

Subject: English
QuestionText: The conclusion introduces new evidence that was not in the body.

Subject: English
QuestionText: Varying sentence length can improve the rhythm and clarity of prose.
